content:
• Monday, December 12, 2016
  • RVNC

    Revance's lead product candidate shows encouraging treatment effect in movement disorder of the neck; shares ahead 5% after hours

    • Preliminary results from a Phase 2 clinical trial assessing Revance Therapeutics' (NASDAQ:RVNC) lead product candidate DaxibotulinumtoxinA for Injection (RT002) for the treatment of adults with moderate-to-severe isolated cervical dystonia showed a positive and durable treatment effect.
    • The 37-subject study features three cohorts delineated by dose. All patients are being followed for 24 weeks after the four-week treatment period.
    • Efficacy was measured by the change from baseline in the total score of a scale called TWSTRS. Treatment with RT002 produced a 38% average reduction in TWSTRS score across all three cohorts. In cohort 1 (mean dose of 174 units) the average reduction was 44% at the end of the treatment period but eased a bit to 33% 24 weeks later.
    • The mean duration of effect was at least 24 weeks in cohort 1 and at least 16 weeks in cohort 2. RT002 was generally safe and well-tolerated across the three groups.
    • Final results should be available in H1 2017.
    • The current treatment for cervical dystonia is an injection of botulinum toxin every three months.
    • RT002 is also being developed to treat frown lines.
    • Shares are up 5% after hours on light volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:50 PM
  • INOV

    Inovalon -33% after cutting 2016 guidance

    • Inovalon (NASDAQ:INOV) -33% AH after cutting guidance for FY 2016 earnings and sales, citing its inability to enter into an expected collaboration agreement with a counterparty.
    • INOV now sees FY 2016 non-GAAP EPS of $0.32-$0.33 vs. earlier guidance of $0.39-$0.46 and $0.44 analyst consensus, on a reduced revenue outlook of $426M-$428M from $470M-$490M and $473M consensus.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:45 PM
  • GLUU

    Glu Mobile reports owning all of Crowdstar after $45M pursuit

    • In a filing, Glu Mobile (GLUU -6.4%) notes it's taken 100% ownership of Crowdstar after a two-step process.
    • In early November, the game maker took a controlling interest in Crowdstar, which makes fashion and styling games for women.
    • In a first step, some Crowdstar stockholders tendered their shares in accordance with a drag-along provision. A second step combined in Crowdstar via a short-form merger, making it a wholly owned subsidiary of Glu.
    • Glu says that after all payments are done, it will have paid about $45.5M to take total control.
    • Previously: Glu Mobile rolls out 'Design Home' decorating game (Nov. 17 2016)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:51 PM | 8 Comments
  • SBGI

    Sinclair Broadcast looking to stretch out loan terms

    • Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI -5.9%) is working to extend maturities of loans at its Sinclair Television Group.
    • The company looks to extend maturities of Term B loans out to January 2024, from April 2020 and July 2021. It's also seeking to reduce pricing terms for the loans and its revolving credit, along with revisions to some covenant ratio requirements.
    • Previously: Sinclair lifts Solomon to COO of Circa (Dec. 12 2016)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:41 PM | 1 Comment

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: ABUS +15%. SUPN +11%. HMHC +2.4%. ARNC +3.1%. DRQ +2.1%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25 p.m.: INOV -31.3%. AKAO -9.1%. NSA -3.4%. WWE -3.0%. ARE -2.9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:31 PM | 2 Comments
  • FOX

    Reuters: Fox set to pursue scheme of arrangement in bid for Sky

    • Twenty-First Century Fox (FOX -6.2%, FOXA -6.6%) is looking to solidify a firm cash offer of about £14.2B for broadcaster Sky (OTCPK:SKYAY -1.3%) as soon as Wednesday via a scheme of arrangement, Reuters reports.
    • That setup would ease the requirements for the takeover's passage, to 75% shareholder approval from a straight-takeover 90%, and is not uncommon in friendly takeovers in the UK.
    • A firm offer on the table could lead to some small shareholders pushing for a higher price, since several have already questioned the quick greenlight from Sky's independent committee.
    • Fox already owns 39% of Sky, and taking over the rest would mean the completion of a 2010 attempt derailed by a phone-hacking scandal at News Corp. newspapers.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:03 PM
  • MIK

    Michaels insiders cashing out

    • Selling stockholders are offering 12M shares, and Michaels (NASDAQ:MIK) intends to purchase 2M of those at whatever price the underwriter (Credit Suisse) pays.
    • The stock's lower by 1.8% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:01 PM
  • STAY

    Extended Stay backers cash in some shares

    • Extended Stay America (NYSE:STAY) holders Centerbridge Partners, Blackstone, and Paulson & Co. are selling 12.5M shares in a secondary offering. The company will receive no proceeds.
    • With the sale, that trio will no longer own a majority of the company; STAY will thus cease to be a "controlled company" based on NYSE standards.
    • Shares -1.9% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:57 PM
  • AKAO

    Achaogen launches 5.75M-share stock offering; shares down 11% after hours

    • Taking quick advantage of today's plazomicin-stoked up move, Achaogen (NASDAQ:AKAO) commences a public offering of 5.75M shares of common stock. Underwriters over-allotment is an additional 862.5K shares. Price and terms have yet to be announced.
    • Net proceeds will fund the ongoing development and potential commercialization of plazomicin, working capital and general corporate purposes.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:56 PM | 26 Comments
  • NSA

    National Storage -3% on capital raise

    • National Storage Trust (NYSE:NSA) is selling 4.5M shares, with underwriter greenshoe of 675K shares.
    • The stock's lower by 2.95% after hours, and up 70% from its IPO about 18 months ago.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:52 PM | 2 Comments
  • NVCR

    Novocure presents positive TTFields data at R&D day; shares ahead 6% after hours

    • Novocure (NASDAQ:NVCR) is up 6% after hours on light volume in response to two announcements of positive data related to its Tumor Treating Fields (TTFields) that were presented at its research and development day.
    • The first presentation included data from a Phase 2 pilot study, PANOVA, that suggested TTFields plus first-line chemotherapies nab-paclitaxel and gemcitabine may be tolerable and safe in patients with advance pancreatic cancer. The data also suggested that the addition of TTFields to the doublet chemo may improve the one-year survival rate.
    • The other presentation was data from another Phase 2 pilot study, INNOVATE, which suggested that TTFields, in combination with weekly paclitaxel, is safe and tolerable in patients with recurrent ovarian cancer and may extend progression-free survival and overall survival compared to paclitaxel alone. Preparations are underway for a Phase 3 study in recurrent ovarian cancer.
    • Data from both studies will be submitted for presentation at an upcoming medical conference.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:45 PM | 6 Comments

  • Boeing hikes dividend 30%, launches new buyback

    • Taking some of the sting out of a 777 production cut, Boeing boosts its quarterly dividend by 30% to $1.42 per share, and replaces its existing buyback plan with a new one for $14B. The annualized dividend yield is 3.6%.
    • The company used up half of last December's $14B authorization this year. Buybacks are expected to begin again in January.
    • Down more than 2% earlier in the after hours session, the stock's now ahead by 0.95%.
    • Previously: Boeing down after hours on 777 production cut (Dec. 12)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:35 PM | 12 Comments
  • WWE

    WWE boosts guidance on network subscriptions

    • World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE -1.7%) is raising guidance for Q4's average subscribers, and reaffirming its outlook for operating income and OIBDA.
    • The company now expects at least 1.4M average paid subs to its WWE Network for the quarter.
    • It still sees OIBDA of $20M-$24M (vs. consensus for $21.9M) and operating income of $12M-$16M.
    • For the full year, that means an outlook for OIBDA of $80M-$84M and operating income of $54M-$58M, and average paid subs to WWE Network of about 1.42M (25% Y/Y growth).
     
     
     
     
    | 4:31 PM | 3 Comments
  • ACIU

    AC Immune's crenezumab-stoked up move short lived; shares down 16%

    • AC Immune (ACIU -15.5%) is flirting with a complete round trip from Friday's almost 24% jump. Shares perked up on Friday after the company announced a data presentation by collaboration partner Genentech (OTCQX:RHHBY) late Friday afternoon. The data, supporting the rationale and early clinical results of lead product candidate crenezumab, were presented at the CTAD meeting in San Diego. The company says data from an exposure-response model predict an improved outcome of the Phase 3 CREAD study in patients with prodromal-to-mild Alzheimer's disease.
    • Investors cooled off considerably today when, apparently, realism set in about the expected 2020 read-out for top-line results from CREAD.
    • Crenezumab is a fully humanized IgG4 monoclonal antibody that binds to all forms of misfolded Abeta proteins, especially Abeta oligomers, to prevent and break up Abeta aggregation and promote Abeta disaggregation. Tau and beta amyloid (Abeta) are associated with neurodegeneration. Tangles and aggregations in the brain characterize Alzheimer's disease.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:59 PM
  • AUY

    Yamana Gold, Tahoe Resources, Alamos Gold upgraded at RBC

    • RBC Capital upgrades gold miners Yamana Gold (AUY +1.7%), Tahoe Resources (TAHO +3.3%) and Alamos Gold (AGI +7.2%) to Outperform from Sector Perform (I, II, III) with respective price targets of $4.50, $19 and $8.50, as the firm sees gold entering a period of seasonal strength.
    • RBC expects AUY to outperform peers given leverage to gold and attractive valuation, forecasts strong free cash flow for TAHO driven by low-cost silver and gold production from mines in Guatemala, Peru and Canada, and sees AGI benefiting from drill-bit driven value creation at Mulatos and continued operational gains at Young-Davidson.
    • However, RBC downgrades Gold Fields (GFI +1%) to Sector Perform from Outperform, as a possible M&A overhang, near-term balance sheet pressure and cautious sentiment around South Deep lead it to believe investors will prefer lower-risk investment alternatives.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:55 PM | 17 Comments
  • VIA

    Viacom officially ends exploration of CBS purchase

    • Alongside that announcement, the Viacom (VIA -7.9%), (VIAB -9.6%) board has made permanent, acting President and CEO Bob Bakish's position.
    • As for a Verizon (VZ +0.7%)/CBS (CBS -0.8%) tie-up, Jefferies' John Janedis isn't feeling it, noting any CBS M&A deals are going to be about TV-centric/content-related assets, rather than cable networks and film.
    • Previously: CBS returns to green as Verizon purchase rumors get wider play (Dec. 12)
    • Previously: National Amusements push CBS and Viacom to standalone track (Dec. 12)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:47 PM | 4 Comments
  • SLCA

    It's "hard to think of a better short" than U.S. Silica, DA Davidson says

    • U.S. Silica (SLCA -5.5%) is downgraded to Underperform from Neutral with a $42 price target at DA Davidson, which says shares have surged nearly 200% YTD and the trade "has more than run its course."
    • The firm says it is “hard to think of a better short” than SLCA, since the stock would likely continue to underperform the group due to “drag from its ISP segment, acquisition/integration risk, its premium valuation and management’s misguided belief that you can consolidate a fragmented industry selling a commodity product without barriers or lead-time to entry.”
    • Bullishness around the shares has been driven by expectations of sand demand moving up the frac sand cost curve as demand increases, but Davidson thinks "it’s safe to assume any frac sand mine or logistics transaction pre-downturn have failed to meet return expectations" after prolonged weakness in crude prices.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:38 PM | 8 Comments
  • NTR

    Agrium downgraded at AltaCorp following recent run-up

    • Agrium (AGU -1.7%) is downgraded to Sector Perform from Outperform with a $107 price target at AltaCorp Capital, as the stock's 20%-plus surge in recent weeks fully reflects the upside provided by its merger with Potash Corp. (POT -1.9%)
    • The firm thinks the move likely reflects some optimism on rebounding fertilizer prices and AGU's pending merger with POT, as well as a general flight to quality and yield chasing among investors.
    • Shareholders approved the merger last month, and the regulatory climate in Canada appears to support the deal, so investors are assigning a high likelihood to a successful closing.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:20 PM | 1 Comment
  • VIA

    Disney's 'Moana' ekes out third straight week atop U.S. box office

    • Moana (DIS -0.8%) held off a hard charge from new entrant Office Christmas Party (VIA -7.4%, VIAB -8.5%) to sit atop the box office for the third straight week.
    • Disney's animated offering drew a strong $18.8M against OCP's $17.5M. Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (TWX -0.5%) grossed $10.8M in its fourth week to settle into the third spot, ahead of Arrival (VIA, VIAB; $5.6M) and Doctor Strange (DIS; $4.6M).
    • Moana's now grossed $145M domestically in its three weeks, and $241M on a worldwide basis. For its part, Fantastic Beasts inched to a cumulative $199.3M domestically and $682.6M worldwide.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:07 PM | 17 Comments

  • Technology - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 3:00 pm

    • Gainers: NEON +12%. QNST +8%. INVE +8%. OIBR.C +7%. RVLT +7%.
    • Losers: HMNY -16%. OTC:FNCX -15%. COOL -14%. SGMA -12%. UNXL -12%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:07 PM
  • AKAO

    Seeking Alpha contributor: Plenty of room to run for Achaogen

    • The author of a well-timed bullish piece on Achaogen (AKAO +141%) two weeks ago, Seeking Alpha contributor Jerome Verony chimes in as the stock rockets higher by 146% following positive Phase 3 results for plazomicin.
    • The "exceptional" results open up further applications for plazomicin beyond cUTI, says Verony. In particular, he says, "plazomicin should see broader use in ESBL-positive infections, potentially replacing colistin in many scenarios."
    • Verony's conservative fair value for AKAO remains at $21, but he reiterates upside nearing $40 per share when commercialization or M&A prospects materialize.
    • Today's more than doubling in price brings the stock to $12.72.
    • Previously: Achaogen's plazomicin successful in late-stage studies; U.S. marketing application on tap for H2 2017; shares up 22% premarket (Dec. 12)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:00 PM | 15 Comments
  • BAS

    Basic Energy gets OK on restructuring, recapitalization plan

    • Basic Energy Services (BAS +5.7%) is higher after obtaining court approval of its prepackaged restructuring and recapitalization plan that equitizes more than $800M of unsecured debt, eliminates $60M in annual cash interest and completes a new capital raise of $125M.
    • The plan provides for a debt-for-equity swap that will result in existing unsecured bond obligations being converted into equity; existing shareholders will receive common stock and warrants in the reorganized company.
    • BAS says it is targeting emergence from Chapter 11 before year-end.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:58 PM | 7 Comments
  • SBGI

    Sinclair lifts Solomon to COO of Circa

    • Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI -5.8%) has promoted John Solomon to chief operating officer of Circa, the news/entertainment brand the company took over this past summer.
    • Solomon had been chief creative officer at the brand.
    • The mobile-friendly, video-driven service has been growing its digital presence, the company says, and recently expanded content offerings with the launch of Circa Laughs and Circa 360.
    • Prior to joining Sinclair, Solomon was editor and VP for content and business development for The Washington Times.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:52 PM
  • AIQ-OLD

    Alliance Group surges on go-private interest

    • Alliance Group's (AIQ-OLD +13.2%) controlling shareholder, Tahoe Investment Group (formerly Fujian Thai Hot Investment), has made a non-binding offer for $9.60 per share in cash for all the stock it currently does not own.
    • Tahoe is a holder of 52% of AIQ.
    • The board has authorized a special committee to look into the proposal.
    • With today's gain, Alliance is up to $9.02.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:21 PM

  • Energy/Materials - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 2:00 pm

    • Gainers: DGAS +8%. SXE +6%.
    • Losers: FCEL -7%. DYN -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:01 PM | 4 Comments
  • CSOD

    D.A. Davidson offers pricing potential for a Cornerstone OnDemand takeout

    • With Cornerstone OnDemand allegedly considering running a formal sale process of its business amid activist pressure, analyst Jack Andrews sees legacy technology companies looking to build and expand on SaaS in the cloud, other human resource technology operations and private equity firms as those to represent possible interest.
    • Suggests a target for takeout in a low-$50s per share range, representing a 6x EV/revenue multiple, and restates Cornerstone OnDemand (CSOD +5.2%) at Buy with a $50 price target (current price $41.24).
     
     
     
     
    | 1:52 PM | 2 Comments

  • Dollar surge pauses ahead of Fed

    • The greenback (UUP -0.6%) today is slumping the most since September, reports Bloomberg, possibly as satiated bulls lighten up ahead of what's universally expected to be a rate hike on Wednesday.
    • The "buy the rumor, sell the news" mood seems likely to continue at least all the way through that Wednesday announcement.
    • ETFs: UUP, UDN, USDU
     
     
     
     
    | 1:33 PM | 4 Comments
  • LMT

    Rough session for defense ETFs as Trump takes on F-35 costs

    • Not only is F-35 maker Lockheed Martin slumping after the president-elect said costs are out of control, but program suppliers like Northrop Grumann, UTX, and BAE Systems are down.
    • The iShares U.S. Aerospace & Defense ETF (ITA -1.3%), the SPDR S&P Aerospace & Defense ETF (XAR -1.5%), the PowerShares ETF Trust Aerospace & Defense Portfolio (PPA -1.4%).
    • Presciently on Friday, JPMorgan was out with a cautious note on Lockheed Martin (LMT -3.1%), suggesting it was next in line for a Trump tweet. The negative impact, however, could be short-lived: "While [the DoD] can push for tougher terms, there is no alternative to F-35 for the U.S. and its allies ... In a worst case, F-35 margins will disappoint but the build rate should increase substantially. Nevertheless, administration efforts to change the contracting equation are a risk for the whole industry and one we’ll be monitoring.”
     
     
     
     
    | 1:27 PM | 2 Comments
  • LMT

    F-35 suppliers also slide following derisive Trump tweet

    • Pres.-elect Trump's broadside (I, II) against the Pentagon’s most expensive weapons system isn't just slamming Lockheed Martin (LMT -3.4%); nearly every major defense contractor except Boeing has exposure to the F-35 fighter jet program.
    • Northrop Grumann (NOC -3.8%), a major supplier to the F-35, is suffering comparable losses, and suppliers United Technologies (UTX -0.1%) and BAE Systems (OTCPK:BAESY -1.5%) also are lower.
    • "Trump has clearly learned that bully pulpit of Twitter can be pretty powerful," says Cowen defense stock analyst Cai von Rumoh. "Defense is in essence a political business, so if the president or president-elect says you're asking too much money, people worry."
    • But investors should not panic over F-35’s prospects based on a single Trump tweet, says Byron Callan, a defense analyst at Capital Alpha: “Stating that costs are ‘out of control’ is wrong. Yes, there are affordability issues on the F-35 and there may be alternative ways to deliver capabilities offered by the F-35 through other platforms or weapons. However, unit prices have been declining, and the program has stabilized in recent years.”
     
     
     
     
    | 1:13 PM | 90 Comments
  • PARNF

    Parnell Pharma to move to OTC Pink; shares slump 23%

    • Thinly traded nano cap Parnell Pharmaceuticals (PARN -23.1%) announces that it will seek to move from the Nasdaq OMX Global Market to the OTC Pink Open Market. The company says the cost savings justify the move as it advances to profitability next year.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:07 PM
  • CBS

    CBS returns to green as Verizon purchase rumors get wider play

    • CBS, trading in the red all morning, made its move into positive ground after CNBC broadcast a piece of a rumor (though skeptically) that showed up in the New York Post this morning: That Verizon (VZ +1%) was "poking around" CBS for a possible purchase.
    • CBS was down as much as 5.2% before jumping to a 2.7% gain this hour. Shares are falling back to a 0.7% gain.
    • CBS and Viacom (VIA -6.2%, VIAB -7.7%) traded down this morning on news that the Redstones were scuttling plans to merge the two companies.
    • While Verizon-CBS rumors look shaky, a possible peg for Verizon's interest would be AT&T's pending $85B deal to acquire Time Warner.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:05 PM | 14 Comments
  • CMC

    Steel prices should rise in H1 2017, Jefferies says, but downgrades CMC, WOR

    • Steel markets seem to be hitting a "cyclical sweet spot," Jefferies analysts say, predicting U.S. and European steel prices likely will rise significantly into H1 2017, backed by a raw materials cost push, seasonally stronger demand and lower imports.
    • Yet Jefferies downgrades Commercial Metals (CMC -0.9%) to Hold from Buy with a $24 stock price target and Worthington Industries (WOR -3.3%) to Underperform from Hold with a $45 target, as it sees “limited upside for some equities” and the risk of a near-term pullback in view of the recent sector rally.
    • CMC offers attractive construction exposure but valuation seems stretched and margins could come under pressure, and WOR is trading at peak multiples with upside limited by autos appearing poised to plateau, the firm says.
    • Jefferies maintains Buy ratings and lifts its price targets for AK Steel (AKS -2.6%), Nucor (NUE -1.9%), Steel Dynamics (STLD -0.3%) and ArcelorMittal (MT +0.8%).
     
     
     
     
    | 1:02 PM | 5 Comments

  • Financials - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 1:00 PM

    • Gainers: MBTF +6%. CTF +6%. FUNC +6%.
    • Losers: MDLY -11%. CPSS -7%. EZPW -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:00 PM

  • Consumers - Top Gainers / Losers as of 12.50

    • Gainers: CYRX +8%. OBCI +6%.
    • Losers: JOUT -14%. OTC:FENX -10%. BDE -7%. RELV -7%. VNCE -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:53 PM
  • WLL

    Whiting gets price target boost at Wunderlich after debt conversion

    • Whiting Petroleum (WLL +1.7%) is maintained with a Hold rating but an improved stock price target of $13, raised from $9, at Wunderlich after the company announced a conversion of $721M of mandatory convertible notes into WLL stock.
    • Wunderlich says WLL on Friday traded above $8.75 for 20 of 30 days, which forced the conversion of debt into 77.6M common shares; while the outcome was expected, the fact that it actually happened provides clarity and reduces an overhang on the stock.
    • The firm also suggests the debt conversion signifies the completion of multiple initiatives the company has undertaken over the past two years to improve its balance sheet.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:49 PM | 6 Comments
  • CF

    CF Industries downgraded at Barclays as shares pricing in optimistic view

    • CF Industries (CF -4.8%) plunges after Barclays downgrades shares to Equal Weight from Overweight even as it raises its price target to $30 from $25, saying the stock now appears to fully price in an optimistic - but not unattainable - rebound in fertilizer market conditions.
    • The firm notes CF has rallied as stronger urea prices have corresponded with capacity cuts overseas, higher global coal prices, reduced U.S. imports and the pivot in sentiment toward materials-related stocks following the election.
    • Barclays sees a more modest recovery into 2018, given that the market “has clearly re-rated” CF on upside potential, but the firm does not expect a valuation expansion reversal in the near-term.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:31 PM | 6 Comments
  • SYNA

    Synaptics downgraded to Underperform at Oppenheimer & Co.

    • Analyst Andrew Uerkwitz, lowering Synaptics from Perform, cites unfavorable market and customer demand, increasing competition within the fingerprint sensor field, strain on margins resulting from TDDI ramp, DDIC decline projected to quicken on increased OLED display penetration and concern Synaptic's OLED DDIC won't meaningfully contribute until 2018.
    • Further considers company underprepared for a shift by OEMs to front fingerprint sensors and expresses additional concern over Samsung Electronics' licensing agreement with Precise Biometrics.
    • Sets target on Synaptics (NASDAQ:SYNA) at $45 (current price $54, -4.22% on the day).
     
     
     
     
    | 12:28 PM | 1 Comment
  • PEIX

    Pacific Ethanol refinances term debt, acquires grain elevator stake

    • Pacific Ethanol (PEIX +4.7%) is higher after reaching an agreement to refinance $155M in term debt it says will reduce interest costs by $8M/year and total debt outstanding by more than $12M.
    • PEIX says it won a new $64M five-year term amortizing loan and a $32M revolving line of credit secured by its Pekin assets, and will obtain $55M from a three-year senior note offering secured by its ownership interest in its western assets.
    • PEIX also will form a new company with Aurora Cooperative Elevator in which it will contribute its Aurora plant assets with ACEC contributing its Aurora west grain elevator, loop track, related land and other assets; PEIX also will sell a 14% interest in pal to ACEC for $30M.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:21 PM
  • RDS.A

    Noble Corp. sinks as Shell idles two drillships

    • Royal Dutch Shell (RDS.A +1.3%) says it is idling two Noble Corp. (NE -3.7%) ultra-deepwater drillships, citing the current, challenging environment for offshore exploration and production projects.
    • Shell says it will idle the Noble Globetrotter II for up to two years, starting in January, during which it will pay a negotiated dayrate of $185K, and idle the Noble Bully II for up to a year at a negotiated dayrate of $200K.
    • The primary term for the Noble Bully II, Noble Globetrotter I and Noble Globetrotter II are unchanged, with contracts expected to conclude in April 2022, July 2022 and September 2023, respectively.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:56 AM | 19 Comments
  • ANET

    Needham & Company, JMP Securities restate confidence on Arista Networks following Cisco patent ruling [updated]

    • The U.S. International Trade Commission ruled Friday infringement by Arista Networks of two of six patents held by Cisco Systems.
    • While Arista Networks itself remains assured on the case, corroborating sentiment is issued by Alex Henderson at Needham & Company (Buy rating) and Erik Suppiger at JMP Securities (Outperform), the latter raising target on shares to $115 (current price $91.96) and considering any weakness a buying opportunity.
    • Arista Networks (NYSE:ANET) shares are trading to 2.6% losses on the session at midday in spite of the encouraging notes.
    • Update: Further, overall bullish, analyst commentary.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:52 AM
  • CVX

    Production still out at unit of Chevron's Gorgon LNG plant, lifting spot prices

    • Chevron (CVX +1.8%) says its Gorgon liquefied natural gas plant off western Australia still has one of its two production units shut after first being taken offline nearly two weeks ago.
    • The latest in a string of outages to hit the $54B project since it began production in March has helped to propel Asian LNG spot prices to levels last reached in mid-2015, Reuters reports.
    • CVX says exports from the plant's second production line, Train 2, resumed on Dec. 8 after a temporary halt on Dec. 7.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:41 AM | 1 Comment
  • MCC

    Medley Capital lower after losing sell-side friend

    • Janney's Mitch Penn downgrades Medley Capital (MCC -4%) to Neutral from Buy following last week's earnings, citing another decline in book value and the potential for a dividend cut.
    • Book value as of Sept. 30 of $9.49 fell from $9.76 three months earlier, and $11 a year previous.
    • Janney's new fair value estimate for the stock is $8.50 vs. Friday's close of $7.40 and the current $7.10.
    • Source: TheFly
    • Related: Medley Management (MDLY -6.7%)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:38 AM | 13 Comments
  • FINL

    Footwear stocks decline after analysts warn

    • Shoe stocks are laggards in the retail sector as some negative analyst notes sway sentiment. Brean Capital downgraded Finish Line (FINL -3.3%) on valuation concerns and Stifel Nicolaus warned on near-term pressure for Crocs (CROX -2.6%). Proper valuation in the post-election environment is a hot-button topic in the footwear sector.

  • RDHL

    RedHill Bio's RHB-104 maintains treatment effect in MS patients 24 weeks after ceasing therapy; shares up 12% premarket

    • Thinly traded micro cap RedHill Biopharma (NASDAQ:RDHL) is up 12% premarket, albeit on only 300 shares, in response to its announcement of positive results from the 24-week follow-up segment of a Phase 2a proof-of-concept clinical trial assessing combination antibiotic RHB-104 for the treatment of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS).
    • The study, CEASE-MS, assessed RHB-104 as add-on therapy to interferon beta-1a in 18 RRMS patients for 24 weeks followed by a 24-week follow-up period with interferon beta-1a only.
    • The annualized relapse rate was 0.0 at both week 24 and week 48 in the per-protocol (PP) population and 0.288 and 0.29, respectively, in the modified intent-to-treat population (mITT), both superior to interferon beta-1a alone [Biogen's (NASDAQ:BIIB) Avonex (0.67) and EMD Serono's Rebif (0.87 - 0.91).].
    • In the PP population, 100% of the patients were relapse-free at both week 24 and week 48. In the mITT population, the proportions were 88% and 93%, respectively, higher than Rebif's 75% and Avonex's 63% (previously reported data).
    • The company's analysis of the data is ongoing and will determine the next step in development. A Phase 3 study in Crohn's disease is in process.
    • Previously: Interim data encouraging for RedHill's RHB-104 in MS; shares up 2% premarket (March 31)
     
     
     
     
    | 9:26 AM | 2 Comments

  • AKAO

    Achaogen's plazomicin successful in late-stage studies; U.S. marketing application on tap for H2 2017; shares up 22% premarket

    • Thinly traded micro cap Achaogen (NASDAQ:AKAO) is up 22% premarket on robust volume in response to its announcement of positive results from two Phase 3 studies assessing lead product candidate plazomicin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic.
    • The first, EPIC, demonstrated that plazomicin was non-inferior (no worse than) meropenem related to the FDA's endpoints and superior to meropenem in terms of the European Medicines Agency's endpoints in patients with complicated urinary tract infections (cUTI) and acute pyelonephritis (AP).
    • The second study, CARE, showed a lower rate of mortality or serious disease-related complications in patients treated with plazomicin compared to colistin therapy, one of the few remaining antibiotics used to treat infections due to carbapenem-resistant Enteroacteriaceae (CRE). At day 28, all-cause mortality or significant diseae-related complications was 23.5% in the plazomicin cohort versus 50.0% in the colistin group. All-cause mortality at day 28 also favored plazomicin, 11.8% versus 40.0%.
    • Plazomicin was well-tolerated with no new safety issues identified. The incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events related to renal function was 3.6% for plazomicin and 1.3% for meropenem.
    • The company plans to submit a New Drug Application (NDA) to the FDA in H2 2017 and a Marketing Authorization Application (MAA) to the European Medicines Agency (EMA) in 2018.
    • Management will host a conference call this morning at 8:30 am ET to discuss  the data.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:45 AM | 10 Comments
